description: From Late Latin implētiō (past participle of Latin impleō (“I fill up”) + -iō); see also implement.

entries.meaning: An act of filling; the state of being full.
examples: Irregular metamorphoses of flowers are extremely common, and usually consist either of an actual muliplication of petals, or of the transformation of stamens and pistils into petals ; the effect of these chages being the formation of double flowers, the impletion of which appears to take place in different ways in different plants.

entries.meaning: A substance which fills, a filling.
